comments.commentBody: Thanks, Jerrold! I made the correction.

I haven't looked over this problem until right now, but I just noticed what seems to be a mistake in the above description of the problem.

The complete factorization of 48 is given as 2 x 2 x 2 x 3.
They left out one of the 2's.
It should say 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 x 3.

LL, Don't tell us the InchWorm stretched all the way from the I to the W...Yeech!

Howie

Karen,
I agree about the unnecessary focus on debt and deficits and that the correct focus should have been on the economy for the past 4 years. That said, the big kahuna in spending is the private healthcare delivery system that both medicare and the privately insured rely on and which is unsustainable for both, but it is mostly not being addressed. None of this is ideology as it is supported by the basic numbers - it only has political implications because of how far some people are from the facts.

I disagree that they are not fooling anyone - they have mostly the same choir as in 2012's election.

John,
I'd say the conservative problem is THE binding constraint at the moment, far in excess of the democrat problem/constraint.

Social Security has nothing whatsoever to do with the debt. Social Security has not increased the debt by one red cent. The money collected by FICA can only be used for the purposes and programs in the Social Security program.

I wish I could agree with your statement that the Republicans' "blame game is fooling nobody".
If that were the case there would be much more noise about it, and the MSM, who seem to revel in false equivalences, would be screaming about it.
Many conservative Americans have swallowed the GOP line about debt being the problem, and he fix is to take money fom the poor, who are unworthy. The solution- to reverse the growing wealth inequality - is rarely mentioned, except for some excellent pieces in he NYT, unread by the masses. Obama's weak proposals for a few selected changes to the tax code won't begin to fix the inequalities. It's sad to say, but he and many Democrats are afraid of and beholden to, Wall Street, Big Pharma, Big Agriculture, Big Oil......until they get brave enough to walk away from those special interests and do what's right, the economy will continue to stagger with the Republicans blaming Obama, as growing numbers of people begin to believe at lie.
Frustrating.

As bad as the sequester is, the White House's proposal to mix unnecessary deficit reduction with some token revenue increases is anything but a "balanced approach". Replacing Sequestration with a Grand Bargain is a terrible idea. We'd be forced to choose between the chained CPI method of cutting Social Security benefits and the current draconian cuts to poverty programs. That is a choice we should not be required to make.

A much better solution is the "Back to Work" budget being offered by the Progressive Congressional Caucus. Of all the plans, it is the only one addressing our most critical problem -- chronic unemployment. With a goal of immediately creating seven million new jobs, it calls for training, emergency unemployment benefits, a public works infrastructure repair program, public school funding and teacher re-hiring. It imposes a financial transaction tax on Wall Street trades, increased taxes on the wealthiest, a health care public option and expanded Medicaid, penalties to corporations that off-shore jobs, an end to oil and gas subsidies, and reduced Pentagon spending.

Polls show that the Republicans have been rapidly losing in public opinion polls, and their latest blame game stunt is fooling nobody. If the Democrats don't want to lose their own support and credibility, they won't make any more deals with the devil. They, too, should pay attention to polls that show jobs are our top priority. And they will mess with Social Security at their own peril.

I read that Scientific American article which showed no understanding of the Paleo diet which was never intended to duplicate early primate diets.  The massive brain expansion from Australopithecines to Homo Erectus was fueled by meat. The Stone Age Hadza in East Africa thrive on  honey, yam-like tubers, birds and bush babies.  No fungus covered leaves  or termites there.  We can all agree that grains and dairy played no role at all the evolution of the human gut. It is also sad that road kill here in Montana is usually wasted.
Another case of politicians as prostitutes, who rent out their oaths of office to the voters and Constitution to those who pay for their political campaigns. Moderate Republicans are an oxymoron.
When they look in the mirror, they see nothing, not even themselves. Why? Because they are vampires and vampires have no reflective properties.

@Rima, shouldn't all the children be required to work for their lunch and not just the poor? After all the school lunch program is subsidized with federal money. But no, we must punish poor children for being poor, that'll teach 'em to pick better parents and circumstances. Can these despicable "congress critters" possibly sink any lower? Maybe we should make these kids work for their education as well! How they can spout "Christian" moralities while supporting ever more draconian cuts is beyond my comprehension. Now there are, I think 7 states, including Maryland!!?, proposing legislation which will not allow any one to hold elected office unless they profess a belief in God. This is beyond the pale and such a slap in the face to the Constitution and the seperation of church and state.What will be next; if you're Gay, brown eyed, left handed, female, Black? These treasonous "representatives" have no regard for any constitutional law that they oppose and believe the constitution begins and ends with the 2nd ammendment. Our country is suffering from some form of collective hysteria and it doesn't look like there is any way to cure us. Maybe we, the citizens, should write the chambers of commerce of these states and their tourist bureaus as well and tell them we will not be spending one dime in their state until they get a grip on the hysteria that has taken over their body politic. Money is the only thing that talks, so let's talk the talk and walk the walk. Not 1 more dime!!

Senator Susan Collins of Maine, a supposed moderate Republican, sees the newest wave of cuts as a "manufactured crisis." Apparently, it is perfectly fine to deprive hungry children of a nutritious breakfast to protect the interests of big agriculture but a major problem to inconvenience air travelers' business trips or vacations.

They are shameless in their need to push the "haves" to the front of every line while they tell hungry children to step aside because there's no breakfast for them anymore.

When they look in the mirror, how can they not see the meanness staring back at them and hang their heads in shame?

steve l, We took a Pole and decided your Kolwalskistan was a "Killer" so, how long did you wrestle with that prior to posting?

Howie TBOQ
I don't know about you, but I didn't "forge" anything.  I discovered it and later, after some difficulty, accepted it.  Straight parents, by the way.

@Paul Can you clarify? Hype about what? The picture shows contrast and change.

The sari---for thousands of years the draped attire of Indian women---is fast disappearing, especially among the young urban set. The swiftness of the change is very similar to what happened in the west during and immediately after the first world war when ankle length skirts disappeared and hemlines rose to just below the knee, or in southeast Asia in the 70s when the sarong made a similar quick exit.

In India, the sari has been replaced by jeans, salwars (loose harem pants), or churidars (tight pants increasingly made of spandex and bunched up above the ankle), like the kind the woman is wearing. The scooter has become the vehicle of choice of females between 13 and 25. I commonly see two or three teenage girls on a scooter on their carefree way to somewhere.

Most females don't wear helmets, though it is mandatory for the men. The government tried to mandate the same for women, but they protested that it flattened the coiffure. The woman isn't veiled, she's dressed that way to keep the dust and pollution out (for reasons of both health and vanity), Some women also wear what look like arm-length formal gloves to keep the dust and sun out (also for reasons of health and vanity.)
What the hell is the HYPE about, all the time ??????

“The energy of mothering and fathering can be embodied in a single parent, two same sex parents, or in a man- woman relationship. Those roles are not gender specific, nor beyond the skill set of an averagely intelligent and sensitive person, male or female. A good father will have a dose of mothering in them somewhere, or could be entirely mothering, while the woman works. Life is actually very complex and humans and families don't always fit into the 'one size fits all' gender roles or boxes the GOP want us to fill. And it's actually more fun that way, even if it requires you to think for yourself.”

For those of you worried about the children, have to say that some of the brightest, self-assured young adults I know have been raised in families with two moms or two dads--even more than 2 moms after breakups. Conversely, I can point to lots of examples of messed up kids coming from a "traditional" family. Not saying that either one is better. Just suggesting that if this is the best argument one can make for not allowing same sex marriage, it's weak.  There are many abilities that go into being  a great parent. Being able to listen and being open are two that stand out.

I applaud the French for this new social revolution they are leading! We cannot know the value of tradition unless people deviate from tradition. Not every country has a citizenry that is willing to gamble the happiness of millions in order to test an ideal of equality. The French have always been at the forefront of social experiments. Their experiences,e.g., the French Revolution, have provided great lessons to the rest of the world, in particular, to the Founding Fathers of the US. Thank you France, again, for plunging in and testing the waters for the rest of humanity! The more cautious rest of the West and certainly China, recently chastened by the huge human tole of testing leftist ideology, will gratefully learn from your example!

The few Chinese I know have little concern regarding the cleanliness of surrounding environment. I wonder if their lack of care for environment mentality plays any role in the pollution that they face right now. The Japanese went through the same phase but cleaned up their country pretty quickly and efficiently. What takes the Chinese so long?

And to go along with Frank Bruni's column about feral pigs, China has a pig problem also. Last month, more than 16,000 dead pigs were found in tributaries of the Huangpu River, not far from Shanghai, in eastern China.

At the same time, scores of diseased pig carcasses were found miles away in Liuyang River, in the south-central Hunan Province. The large number of dead pigs discovered nationwide caused great public concern.

According to the National Bureau of Statistics, China supplied the market with 700 million pigs in 2012. That’s about half the pig production of the world. Even with a conservative estimate of a natural mortality rate of 3 to 5%, that means 18 to 35 million pigs die of disease annually. Disposing of these carcasses is not simple.

In theory the Chinese government has come up with a sanitary way for farmers to decontaminate and dispose of these carcasses. Diseased animals have to be buried at least 1,5 meters deep or cremated. Farmers can apply to receive a subsidy of 80 Yuan ($12) for each diseased pig they dispose of in this way.

But in practice, dead pig carcasses are most often thrown into rivers or dumped somewhere. A large number of them are sold on the black market, and end up on people’s plates.

With bad air and diseased pigs, China is not the 21st century heaven that their leadership likes to portray.

The dictatorship was Ngo Dinh Diem.

Wow, that sounds ironic. Are you sure this country doesn't have the king at the present?

I can ensure with you, that in this country, we have a king, a queen, and a princess.

And they are drinking Vietnamese Blood day bay day, month by month, year by year, minute by minute, second by second

To those moralizing about the war: if the US had hung in there and held off the communists, the outcome would have been continuation of a brutal, corrupt, and incompetent post-colonial dictatorship. Doesn't anyone remember the buddhist protests? Would that have left Vietnam any better off?

It WILL be interesting to see how this plays out -- and it WILL play out because Vietnam is no North Korea. Dissent is a positive force in Vietnam when it comes from within, but there also a hugely negative element that is being stirred up by the former post-colonial elite from outside of Vietnam (also in their 70s and 80s and also out of ideas) whose only aim is to see a violent end to the communist regime. A sure way for a blogger to attract the attention of the authorities is to come under the influence that group. In the US you would call that inciting terrorism.

Thinker—

it's a miracle! it's like an experiment where a monkey bangs on a keyboard and real, actual english words come out.

next step: logical sentences. i know, i know, there's no way that could really happen, but i keep hoping.

also—why are you defending assad?? of all people. unbelievable. not that the rebels are any better, but still. you're like the tsarnaev brothers' mom who keeps saying they must have been set up.

As a militant Salafist Islamic movement, al-Qaeda preaches a radical anti-Shia ideology that places it firmly at odds with Shia Iran.

In Afghanistan, Iraq and Syria, al-Qaeda has warred with factions and ethnic groups it considers close to Iran.

Despite this enmity, however, al-Qaeda and Iran have tolerated one another where it suited them.

After the defeat of the Taliban in Afghanistan, Iran permitted several top al-Qaeda associates - including one of Osama Bin Laden's wives and several of his children - to live under "house arrest" in eastern Iran.

More recently, Iran has expelled the most senior of those al-Qaeda officials, including Bin Laden's son-in-law Sulaiman Abu Ghaith.

The tougher stance reflects growing tension between Iran's Shia clerics and the Sunni militant group, particularly over the civil war in Syria.

That may explain why the Royal Canadian Mounted Police were quick to point out that investigators have seen no evidence Iran backed this plot

Fact Boy, There's obviously "Method" to your Madness, as your outSTANding comment truly STANds alone and makes me think you were possibly the prized student of the late great Russian actor, teacher and theater director, Constantin STANislavski...Da?

Howie STAN in awe of FB!

Talk about synchronicity. A mole has been making a mess of our garden and today a bobcat got him. He didn't eat him, he just waited patiently for him and dispatched him with a good swipe of his paw. I'm afraid there are more moles, so I can only hope the bobcat still wants to play.

The avatar's namesake is not so much of a problem around here but moles are Public Enemy #1.

Just today, I saw a news item about a West Virginia state legislator who wants school children to work for their school lunches. These people seem proud of their meanness. It isn't enough that they've ruined the lives of millions of workers by not making every effort to boost our economy. Now they're going after kids.

I'm eagerly awaiting the release of China's answer to our countries hugely popular "Ma and Pa Kettle" 1940's film series, rather appropriately called, 'MAH and Pah-joong do Beijing'

Howie TBOQ

I'm in the same position.  I own a business with plenty of cash sitting in the bank, although inflation, low as it is, is still outrunning the meager interest  rate the bank is paying, so I'm actually losing money.  If demand ever picks up I'll be ready; if it doesn't I'll continue to lose money until even increased demand won't help me.  So obviously Obama is the villain in this tale of woe.

I'm sitting on a pile of cash. It's earning an interest rate of 0% sitting in the bank. The corollary of which is that I can borrow money essentially for free. But I can handle all current demand and all the demand as far as I can project, which means there's no rational economic reason to invest in increased capacity or hire new workers.

So, obviously, the only reason I don't invest and hire is that Obama's going to raise my marginal tax rate and Obamacare's going to increase the unit cost of labor a percent or two. Any fool could see that...

I'm guessing that you're raising your own animals in your own backyard? Or going on weekend hunting trips? I hear New Jersey is overrun with deer and bears, so you probably can get lucky a lot of the time; take a camping trip and lure them by leaving your garbage uncovered at night.

Most Americans really do overeat protein, and that leads to a host of degenerative diseases, not the least of which is osteoporosis. Most doctors—who are woefully unschooled in nutrition—advise cramming dairy products to combat osteoporosis. Wrong: when you consume too much animal-based protein, this creates an acid condition of the blood, and to compensate, the body leaches calcium from the bones to neutralize the acidity. Over time, this leads to "dowager's hump" or even a hunchback in men.

Plant proteins are much more easily tolerated by the body; or as another reader suggests, insects have long been a protein source for many cultures, and will probably be important as a future protein source as well, as the population continues to increase and large tracts of land are no longer available for animal agriculture.

(Have you guessed yet? I'm yet another vegan who finds Mark Bittman's assertion that veganism is "too extreme for most people" to be very offensive! It's both easy and a relief to be a vegan—a relief that I'm not burdening our ecosystem with animal carcasses.)

It's worth noting that famine and mass starvation were far more common in the world prior to the modern industrial era.

I don't know if by "food industrialization" you include large-scale farming. According to the definition of "industry" you should, so let's assume the potato had never become "industrialized" in Europe. In that case, it is likely that Europe would look more like large swaths of starving Africa today than anything else, because Europe was certainly headed for steady, everlasting famine just prior to the introduction of the potato (thanks South America!).

Big Food feeds a big world. Maybe Big Food made the big world possible in the first place. Big Food is here to stay, at least I hope it is because I don't want bands of starving marauders roaming my streets.

What we need is Big Food to be run by smarter, more conscientious people. We need Big Food to choose health over profit. A tall order...
No. He got the memo. Very very few want to become vegans. Just the facts, ma'am.
fruit is pure sugar. It counts big time.

Kate, you shouldn't have to starve! I am vegan, and can assure you that you can avoid being ravenous without meat. Try a large helping of homemade muesli for breakfast; what could be easier than putting .5 c of oats, .25 c of raisins, handful of almonds and maybe a few chopped prunes in a bowl with some soy milk? My co-workers get hungry for lunch before I do. For quick lunch, Smuckers all-natural PB and some honey on whole grain bread, throw in 3-4 pieces of fruit. Once upon a time, people really did feel hungry before the next meal. Not ravenous, but truly hungry. That's a good thing. You might also keep raisins, nuts, etc at work for afternoon snacks (though I rarely need them).

I only make smoothies as a dessert or a treat, not as an entree.

I NEVER feel deprived, and I have maintained a healthy BMI for 3+ years as a vegan. Eat as much food as you'd like, so long as It isn't meat, dairy or hyper processed. You will lose weight and feel great. The blood tests don't lie, nor does the scale.

One more thing: I have learned to NEVER make dinner food/recipe choices late in the day, when I am already hungry for dinner... Far better to make a plan at least several hours earlier in the day. Decisions made by 2pm are much healthier.
